field.description: a reference to an ISA mass spectrometry acquisition event
The IUPAC name of the isotopic tracer molecule. e.g. "Uniformly Labeled 13C-Glucose" or "15N Glutamine".

The retention time (MS:1000894), in the context of application using gas or liquid chromatography as separation methods, field is used to report the time elapsed between in sample injection and the moment it shows up in the detector post elution. It is a characteristic of the material of a given chemical class, dependent on chromatography column characteristics and mobile phase. The retention time is usually expressed in Minutes.

unit-field.description: a unit field to qualify the retention time.

field.description: a cluster identifier is an information assigned to uniquely identify a subset of mass spectrometry spectral peaks. MS_1002407 is the identifier for the term in the Mass spectrometry Ontology.

Three-character symbol m/z (MS:1000040) is used to denote the quantity formed by dividing the mass of an ion in unified atomic mass units by its charge number (regardless of sign). The symbol is written in italicized lower case letters with no spaces. Note 1: The term mass-to-charge-ratio is deprecated. Mass-to-charge ratio has been used for the abscissa of a mass spectrum, although the quantity measured is not the quotient of the ion's mass to its electric charge.
a type of m/z signal intensity measured in the context of gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC-MS)
a type of m/z signal intensity about an ion. MS_1000744 is the identifier for the term in the Mass spectrometry Ontology.

Specify the value of the signal intensity and how it was calculated using one of the following values. NOTE: a signal intensity calculation method SHOULD be reported. A Controlled Vocabulary will be provided and will include the following values: Signal intensity of all m/z values after integrating the whole peak of a concrete metabolite and subtracting baseline (this is the ideal, what we report). Signal intensity of all m/z values after integrating the whole peak of a concrete metabolite without subtracting baseline. Signal intensity of all m/z values at the maximum of the peak (also known as maximum signal intensity) and subtracting baseline. Signal intensity of all m/z values at the maximum of the peak (also known as maximum signal intensity) without subtracting baseline.

unit-field.description: Specify the unit used to report the raw signal intensity

field.description: Specify the how the raw signal intensity is calculated.

Specify the value of the signal intensity and how it was calculated using one of the following values. NOTE: a signal intensity calculation method SHOULD be reported. A Controlled Vocabulary will be provided and will include the following values: Signal intensity of all m/z values after integrating the whole peak of a concrete metabolite and subtracting baseline (this is the ideal, what we report). Signal intensity of all m/z values after integrating the whole peak of a concrete metabolite without subtracting baseline. Signal intensity of all m/z values at the maximum of the peak (also known as maximum signal intensity) and subtracting baseline. Signal intensity of all m/z values at the maximum of the peak (also known as maximum signal intensity) without subtracting baseline.

unit-field.description: Specify the unit used to report the corrected signal intensity

field.description: Specify the how the normalized signal intensity is calculated.
field.list-values: "ion suppression bias correction","isotopic natural abundance correction"

field.description: Specify the value of the signal intensity and how it was calculated using one of the following values. NOTE: a signal intensity calculation method SHOULD be reported. A Controlled Vocabulary will be provided and will include the following values: Signal intensity of all m/z values after integrating the whole peak of a concrete metabolite and subtracting baseline (this is the ideal, what we report). Signal intensity of all m/z values after integrating the whole peak of a concrete metabolite without subtracting baseline. Signal intensity of all m/z values at the maximum of the peak (also known as maximum signal intensity) and subtracting baseline. Signal intensity of all m/z values at the maximum of the peak (also known as maximum signal intensity) without subtracting baseline.

unit-field.description: Specify the unit used to report the corrected signal intensity

field.description: Specify the how the normalized signal intensity is calculated.
field.list-values: "peak height with baseline substraction","peak area with baseline substraction","sum of all peaks in each spectrum equal to 1 normalization","area normalization","total ion count normalization", "sum of isotopologue normalization"

field.description: The empirical formula (of the monitored cluster) of a compound is a chemical compound formula formed by juxtaposition of the atomic symbols with appropriate (integer) subscripts to give the simplest possible formula expressing the composition. MS_1000865 is the identifier for the term in the Mass spectrometry Ontology. (from: http://www.chem.uky.edu/courses/che610/JPS_Spring_2007/Formulas.pdf)

A fragment name conventionally named using Cx-Cy where x and y correspond to the carbon number in the metabolite that is being analyzed. x can be 1 or higher and y is lower or equal to n, where n is the total number of carbons of the molecule backbone. For example: glucose has 6 carbons so the complete molecule fragment would be C1-C6. If the indicated fragment is C3-C6 it means that results will refer to the 4 carbons fragment between carbon 3 and carbon 6 of glucose molecule.

To indicate the percentage of fragment molecules that contain 0 13C (m+0), 1 13C (m+1), 2 13C (m+2), ... (y-x+1) 13C (m+y-x+1)). Values can be expressed as a fraction of unity or as percentage. This is usually the data that is most frequently reported in publications. Ideally these values should have been corrected for natural enrichment so that they only take into account the enrichment that comes from the tracer. NOTE: we use 'isotopologue' as synonymous to 'mass isotopomer'
the name of the isotope used in the tracer molecule
the mass to charge (m over z) ratio being monitored and to which the signal intensity corresponds.
Specify the how the normalized signal intensity is calculated.
field.list-values: "adduct correction","isotopic natural abundance correction","adduct and isotopic natural abundance correction"

field.description: A fragment name, conventionally named using Cx-Cy, where x and y correspond to the carbon number in the metabolite that is being analyzed. x can be 1 or higher and y is lower or equal to n, where n is the total number of carbons of the molecule backbone. For example: glucose has 6 carbons so the complete molecular fragment would be C1-C6. If the indicated fragment is C3-C6 it means that results will refer to the 4 carbons fragment between carbon 3 and carbon 6 of glucose molecule.

The empirical formula The IUPAC sensu chemical formula about the molecular fragment associated with the m/z position in the mass spectrometry spectrum. The empirical formula of a compound is a chemical compound formula formed by juxtaposition of the atomic symbols with appropriate (integer) subscripts to give the simplest possible formula expressing the composition. MS_1000865 is the identifier for the term in the Mass spectrometry Ontology.

adduct ion formula specified by the given value. http://fiehnlab.ucdavis.edu/staff/kind/Metabolomics/MS-Adduct-Calculator http://dx.doi.org/DOI:10.1016/S1044-0305(99)00089-6 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22111785 ]
The term SMILES refers to a line notation for encoding molecular structures and specific instances should strictly be called SMILES strings

The IUPAC International Chemical Identifier is a textual identifier for chemical substances, designed to provide a standard way to encode molecular information and to facilitate the search for such information in databases and on the web. Initially developed by IUPAC and NIST from 2000 to 2005, the format and algorithms are non-proprietary
Specify the how chemical assignment is made
field.list-values: "direct assignment to standard","indirect assignment to standard","assignment by database search", "assignment by isotopologue clique method","other"

field.description: indicate the confidence score for the assignment"
The namespace for the database as registered in MIRIAM or FAIRSHARING registry
If available, the identifier minted by CHEBI for the small molecule - metabolite. e.g. "CHEBI:12345".

isotologue abundance relative concentration (also known as 'percentage isotopologue enrichment) The numerical value indicating the relative amount of a given isotopologue (reporting as a percentage). The synonym is "percentage isotopologue enrichment"

unit-field.description: Specify the unit used to report the relative abundance: this corresponds to an amount per unit of normalizer, which can be anything such as 'amount per mL plasma or other biofluid', 'amount per mg protein', 'amount per mole DNA','amount per number of cell', 'other'
